Lake of Egypt
Water Treatment Facility 

Chlorine Risk Management Plan


Policy Statement and Application


The Occupation Safety and Health Administration standard ( 29CFR 1910 119-Process Safety) and Environmental Protection Agency (Clean Air Act 40 CFR Part 68 112(r)(7) Risk Management Rule has established standards pertaining to highly hazardous chemicals.  The purpose of these standards is to establish specific requirements for those companies which use, manufacture, or store highly hazardous chemicals in order to prevent or minimize the effects of catastrophic releases of toxic, reactive, flammable or explosive chemicals.

It is the intent of Lake Egypt Water District to protect it's employees as well as the community it serves from the dangers associated with these chemicals as well as comply with all applicable federal and state standards.  To achieve these goals, specific policies and procedures were established and compiled that pertain to all covered chemicals at or above specific threshold quantities listed in this section of the plan.  The chemical involved at the Lake Egypt Facility is Chlorine.  It is used for the purpose of disinfecting in production processes of potable water (drinking water). The following is to provide a summary and briefing of Lake Egypt Water District's Chlorine Risk Management Plan. 
This facility is sited in a rural area on the north side of Lake Egypt approximately 10 miles south of Marion, Il.  

Document Management System

Lake Egypt Water District has implemented a management system to oversee the implementation of the Chlorine Risk Management Plan elements.

A Management Documentation Chart was designed to show the following information: 
7 Positions and the primary responsibilities of each
7 Positions and areas to monitor for process changes
7 Position and responsibilities when process changes occur

By defining the lines of authority and roles and responsibilities of the management team, our facility can remain committe

d to every element of the Chlorine Risk Management Program. This will ensure a safe chlorinating process for our facility.



Lake Egypt Water District

Safety Assurance and Training:

     At least once every three (3), Lake Egypt Water District shall conduct a compliance audit of the chlorinating process to evaluate compliance with the prevention program requirements. At least one person involved in the audit must be knowledgeable in the chlorinating process. The District will develop a report of the findings and document appropriate responses to each finding. All deficiencies shall be corrected. The District shall retain the two (2) most recent audit reports on-site. 
The OHSA compliance guideline, CPL 2-2.34, is a good starting point for an audit of the prevention program for a water treatment plant. These audits are likely to describe flaws in the management of process safety that could lead to a release of chlorine.
All employees involved in the chlorine process are be trained in the proper operating procedures of the process and in the appropriate safety procedures outlined in the chlorine manuals.  Training emphasizes safety, health hazards, emergency operations, and safe work practices. Employees are provided refresher training on an annual basis. Additional training is available to accommodate employee needs as necessary.
Lake Egypt Water District shall determine that each operator has received and understood the training and maintain the appropriate records for employees with date of their training and the methods used to verify employee understands the training.

Five Year Accident History

There has not been any accidental release of chlorine from a covered process in the five years prior to the submission of a Risk Management Plan at the Lake of Egypt Water Facility.


Chlorine Process Safety Systems and release prevention

A chlorine detector is located in the chlorine room. It monitors the chlorine storage and feed areas. The chlorine alarm provides aud

ible and visual alarms that are set at 3 parts per million (ppm). The alarm shall be checked daily to ensure sure safe operations. If the alarm is activated, alarming will continue until plant personnel acknowledge the alarm.  At this time the Emergence Response Plan for chlorine leaks is as follows. Automatic shut-offs are installed that respond to process failures. The facility is totally enclosed and all building doors are locked to help prevent vandalism. All facility safety procedures (Confined Space Entry, Lockout-Tag-out, etc) are followed during the chlorinating process system. All operating personnel are trained in the response to process failures, leak detection and use of repair kits. Local fire and police and emergency management authorities are notified immediately to any emergency scenarios. Offsite Consequence analysis
For Implementation of Process Safety Management Plan
(In compliance with 29 CFR 1910.11(c)).


Lake of Egypt Water District has performed an offsite consequence analysis to provide information to the government and the public about the potential consequences of an accidental chemical release at this facility.  The offsite consequence analysis (OCA) consists of two elements:

7 A worst-case release scenario 
7 Alternative release scenario.

To simplify the analysis and ensure a common basis for comparisons, EPA has defined the worst-case scenario as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a single vessel or process line failure that results i

n the greatest distance to an endpoint.  In broad terms, the distance to the endpoint is the distance a toxic vapor cloud, heat from a fire, or blast waves from an explosions will travel before dissipating to the point that serious injuries from short-term exposures will no longer occur.

Process Hazard Analysis Methodology

Using CAMEO and ALOHA, software developed and distributed by the US EPA and NOAA, analyses were performed for the maximum release of 245 pounds per minute of chlorine. Under these scenarios, a vulnerability zone of 1.1 miles in diameter was formed. No previous release at this facility ever occurred. Release detection equipment is located in the chlorine storage room. Detection equipment emits a visual and audible warning if gas is leaks out of the container. The vacuum and leak control devices will stop the flow if chlorine leaks are detected.
Consequences of failure of engineering controls are leaks causing the need for employee evacuation and evacuation of near-by residents.
